subsection.title: A Tool for Solving Exponential Equations
subsection.p: Logarithms are functions that, among other things, can be used to solve exponential equations. If we have an exponential equation in which the variable is in the exponent, we use logarithms to isolate the variable.
In other words, given the question I wonder what the exponent is? the answer can found using logarithms.
By definition, a logarithm is an exponent. In the equation b^{y}=x, y is the exponent where y=log_{b}(x)
There are at least three useful rules about logarithms:

li.p: This rule is often used to bring the exponent down from its position above to be in line with the given equation.
This rule (and the one the one that follows) are sometimes used to split equations apart in order to separate the unkown variable from the known values in an equation.

subsection.p: The first rule is the big bread winner. I used to have a pocket knife with 10 different tools folded into it, but I only used one. Rule 1 is that tool. It allows us to take an exponential expression and bring down the exponent so we can isolate it.
If we end up with an equation that looks like (0.337)^{\text{?}}=1.272 as in, I wonder what the exponent is?, we can use a logarithmic function to find the answer.
Although most likely a variable is used instead of a question mark as in (0.337)^{x}=1.272 where x is the unknown value we are trying to find.
Using rule \# 1 and applying any logarithm to both sides of the equation we can work our way towards isolating the unknown variable x.

statement.p: We get the same answer using the natural logarithm, \ln, instead. Try it!

introduction.p: How many 7 \% increases is the same as one 49 \% increase?

statement.p: The growth factor associated with a 7 \% increase is b=
The equation below literally states, An unknown number of growth factors b=1.07 is the same as 1.49
Apply your favorite logarithm to each side of the equation. My favorite is \ln, so the equation is now \ln(1.07)^{x}= \ln(1.49)
Invoke rule \# 1 so that the exponent can come down in front of the expression on the left x \ln(1.07)= \ln(1.49)
Last step, isolate the variable by dividing both sides by \ln(1.07), and what do you get?

subsection.p: Rule \# 1 is great, but if we want to use it as the main tool we have to know when it applies and how to deal with the situation if the rule does not apply.

introduction.p: At first glance it seems you can apply rule \# 1, but is that right? Rule \# 1 states \log_{b}(N^{x})=x \log_{b}(N)

Notice how rule \# 1 assumes you have one side written as x^{N} with nothing else in front (no coefficient)? The left side of our equation has a coefficient of 3 in front of the exponential3(2.83)^{x}. The constant 3 is keeping us from using rule \# 1.
That constant either has to be moved or we have to use another rule (if there is one that applies).
We can fix the situation by rearranging the equation so that it matches rule \# 1 or we could use rule \# 2 because at least it matches our equation.

statement.p: The constant 3 needs to be moved so only the exponential remains on the left side of the equation. (2.83)^{x}=\frac{15}{3} Voilà! Now we have the correct form to use rule \# 1. Apply your favorite logarithm to both sides. I'll use \ln this time because I used \log in the last example \ln (2.83)^{x}= \ln \big( \frac{15}{3} \big) The exponent gets to come down and we have x \ln(2.83)= \ln \big( \frac{15}{3} \big) the last step is to isolate the variable x= \frac{\ln \big( \frac{15}{3} \big)}{\ln(2.83)} so that x \approx 1.547
In English the second rule says, The log of a product is equal to the sum of the logs.

Applying \ln to both sides of our equation, we in fact have the log of the product 3 times (2.83)^{x} on the left side \ln (3(2.83)^{x})=\ln(15) Use rule \# 2 and to write the left side of the equation as the sum of the logs \ln(3)+\ln(2.83)^{x}=\ln(15) Remember the whole point of this is to isolate the variable x which we can now do since on the left side one term has x and the other does not \ln (2.83)^{x}=\ln(15)-\ln(3) Look, we get to use rule \# 1 anyway! On the left we bring down the x x \ln(2.83)=\ln(15)-\ln(3) So we can isolate x x=\frac{\ln(15)-\ln(3)}{\ln(2.83)} We get the same answer as before x \approx 1.547
Which method did you like better?

introduction.p: Of course we could have just solved the equation 3(2.83)^{x}=15 graphically and avoided the algebra all together.

subsection.title: Domain, Range and Graph of Logarithmic Functions
subsection.p: Since logarithms are just another class of fucntions, the logarithm function has a domain and a range and the graph of a logarithmic function has its own characteristics that make it unique.
We can use our language approach to understand the domain of a logarithmic function. The literal translation of the expression log(x) is The power of 10 that gives you x.

li.p: log(100) = 2 because The power of 10 that gives you 100 is 2. Since 10^{2}=100
log_{2}(16) means, The power of 2 that gives you 16.
If you follow the expression with an equals sign you get a complete math sentence log_{2}(16)=4 which says, the power of 2 that gives you 16 is 4. Since 2^{4}=16

subsection.p: Consider the function f(x)=log_{3}(x) where x is the input. The domain of f is the set of all possible inputs the funtion can use or values that make sense for the function.
Consider inputs that are negative, like x=-9 and think about the meaning of log_{3}(-9) which is, What power of 3 gives you -9? Does that even make sense?
If you multiply a bunch of 3's together, how many does it take to get -9? You can't get a negative result if all you have is postive 3's! That is a hint that a logarithms cannot have negative inputs.
For a similar reason logarithic functions cannot have zero as an input. If you ask How many factors of 3 does it take to get 0? or just 3^{?}=0, it should be clear there is no answer.
Therefore, the domain of any logarithmic function is the input must be greater than or equal to zero. In math we say
Just like exponential functions have horizontal asymptotes as in , logarithm functions have vertical asymptotes as in .

subsection.p: The vertical asymptote is like a vertical boundary that the function cannot cross. In the case of the logarithm the asymptote is the y-axis and the funciton only exists to the right of this boundary. Therefore the domain of the log function is, in general, all inputs greater than zero (unless you shift the function around as we will do in another lesson).
